rationale: The agent's implementation has critical correctness issues: it processes long-style options AFTER the getopt parsing loop instead of BEFORE, meaning options are never properly passed to getopt and the script flow is broken. Ground truth correctly parses long options into properties BEFORE calling getopt, then passes the remaining ARGV to getopt. Agent also completely missed the required changes to getopt flags (vfhp:D:X: instead of vdhp:D:X:) and the two documentation files (setup.asciidoc and setup/installation.asciidoc). Additionally, the agent added extensive unsolicited help text and modified elasticsearch.bat (Windows script) which was not in scope. The core algorithm is fundamentally flawed - processing arguments after getopt consumes them makes the feature non-functional. Missing 2 required documentation files is a major completeness issue.
ground_truth_patch:
diff --git a/bin/elasticsearch b/bin/elasticsearch
index 753aa8e0a34..794cd1b0895 100755
--- a/bin/elasticsearch
+++ b/bin/elasticsearch
@@ -150,8 +150,24 @@ launch_service()
     fi
 }
 
+# Parse any long getopt options and put them into properties before calling getopt below
+# Be dash compatible to make sure running under ubuntu works
+ARGV=""
+while [ $# -gt 0 ]
+do
+    case $1 in
+      --*=*) properties="$properties -Des.${1#--}"
+           shift 1
+           ;;
+      --*) properties="$properties -Des.${1#--}=$2"
+           shift 2
+           ;;
+      *) ARGV="$ARGV $1" ; shift
+    esac
+done
+
 # Parse any command line options.
-args=`getopt vdhp:D:X: "$@"`
+args=`getopt vfhp:D:X: $ARGV`
 eval set -- "$args"
 
 while true; do
diff --git a/docs/reference/setup.asciidoc b/docs/reference/setup.asciidoc
index f535c2d1612..799dd47f279 100644
--- a/docs/reference/setup.asciidoc
+++ b/docs/reference/setup.asciidoc
@@ -38,13 +38,13 @@ There are added features when using the `elasticsearch` shell script.
 The first, which was explained earlier, is the ability to easily run the
 process either in the foreground or the background.
 
-Another feature is the ability to pass `-X` and `-D` directly to the
-script. When set, both override anything set using either `JAVA_OPTS` or
-`ES_JAVA_OPTS`. For example:
+Another feature is the ability to pass `-X` and `-D` or getopt long style
+configuration parameters directly to the script. When set, all override
+anything set using either `JAVA_OPTS` or `ES_JAVA_OPTS`. For example:
 
 [source,sh]
 --------------------------------------------------
-$ bin/elasticsearch -Xmx2g -Xms2g -Des.index.store.type=memory
+$ bin/elasticsearch -f -Xmx2g -Xms2g -Des.index.store.type=memory --node.name=my-node
 --------------------------------------------------
 *************************************************************************
 --
diff --git a/docs/reference/setup/installation.asciidoc b/docs/reference/setup/installation.asciidoc
index 5a6f9baf293..3350cd02429 100644
--- a/docs/reference/setup/installation.asciidoc
+++ b/docs/reference/setup/installation.asciidoc
@@ -28,12 +28,12 @@ There are added features when using the `elasticsearch` shell script.
 The first, which was explained earlier, is the ability to easily run the
 process either in the foreground or the background.
 
-Another feature is the ability to pass `-X` and `-D` directly to the
-script. When set, both override anything set using either `JAVA_OPTS` or
-`ES_JAVA_OPTS`. For example:
+Another feature is the ability to pass `-X` and `-D` or getopt long style
+configuration parameters directly to the script. When set, all override
+anything set using either `JAVA_OPTS` or `ES_JAVA_OPTS`. For example:
 
 [source,sh]
 --------------------------------------------------
-$ bin/elasticsearch -Xmx2g -Xms2g -Des.index.store.type=memory
+$ bin/elasticsearch -f -Xmx2g -Xms2g -Des.index.store.type=memory --node.name=my-node
 --------------------------------------------------
 *************************************************************************
